title: As Beyond Meat turns a profit, will Britain get a taste for plant-based meat?
text:
When alternative meat producer Beyond Meat made its stock market debut in May, it was considered the most successful IPO in almost two decades.

Shares soared 163pc on day one of its listing and continued to rise, giving the company a $12bn (£10.1bn) price tag at its peak, despite it never having made a profit.

This week, the producer of the ‘bleeding’ meat-free Beyond Burger, posted its first quarterly profit, raking in $4.1m in the three months to September 29, compared with a $9.3m loss for the same period a year earlier.

But despite the good news, Beyond Meat’s shares tanked as much as 20pc during Tuesday's trading in New York.

Analysts are worried that the company's lofty valuation is hard...
description: When alternative meat producer Beyond Meat made its stock market debut in May, it was considered the most successful IPO in almost two decades.
